fields.label: Why does HMRC asks me about email?
fields.infoText:
Email is not 100% secure, so it is important that you understand the risks before you email us. We’ll not deal with you by email unless you tell us you accept the risks of doing so. 

**The main risks associated with using email that concern HMRC are:**

*confidentiality and privacy – there’s a risk that emails sent over the internet may be intercepted

*confirming your identity – it’s crucial that we only communicate with established contacts at their correct email addresses

*there’s no guarantee that an email received over an insecure network, like the internet, hasn’t been altered during transit

*attachments could contain a virus or malicious code


**How we can reduce the risks**

We’ll desensitise information, for example by only quoting part of any unique reference numbers. We can also use encryption. If you wanrt to do the same, we can discuss how you can still provide the information we need.


**If you don’t want to use email**

You may prefer that we don’t respond by email, for example because other people have access to your email account. If so, we’re happy to respond by an alternative method. We‘ll agree this with you either by telephone, fax or in writing via post.


**If you do want to use email**

If you would like to use email, we’ll need you to confirm in writing by post, email or fax:

*that you understand and accept the risks of using email
*that you’re content for financial information to be sent by email
*that attachments can be used

If you are the authorised agent or representative we’ll need you to confirm in writing by post, email or fax that your client understands and accepts the risks.


**Please also:**

*send us the names and email addresses of all people you would like us to use email with - you, your staff, your representative, your agent, for example  *confirm you have ensured that your spam filters are not set to reject and/or automatically delete HMRC emails


**How we use your agreement**

Your confirmation will be held on file and will apply to future email correspondence. We’ll review the agreement at regular intervals to ensure there are no changes.


**Opting out**

You may opt out of using email at any time by letting us know.


[Find more information on HMRC's privacy policy](www.gov.uk/help/privacy-policy).

fields.helpText: This is called 'HMRC ref' or 'Your ref' on correspondence about this dispute. It is a combination of letters and numbers, for example CFS-123456 or CFSS-1234567.

sections.title: Enter your VAT Registration Number

fields.label: Enter your VAT Registration Number
fields.helpText: Your VAT Registration Number is a 9 digit number supplied when you registered for VAT. For example, 123456789. Please enter the reference with no spaces. You can find it on any correspondence from HM Revenue & Customs relating to your VAT or your VAT certificate.

sections.title: Enter your Unique Taxpayer Reference

fields.label: Enter your Unique Taxpayer Reference
fields.helpText: This is 10 numbers, for example 1234567890. It will be on tax returns and other letters about Corporation Tax or Self Assessment. It may be called 'reference', 'UTR' or 'official use'.

sections.title: Enter your employer PAYE reference

fields.label: Enter your employer PAYE reference
fields.helpText: This is a 3 digit tax office number, a forward slash, and a tax office employer reference, like 123/AB456. It may be called ‘Employer PAYE reference’ or ‘PAYE reference’.

sections.title: Agreement

fields.infoText: Read and agree to these principles before submitting. If we accept your application, you must follow these principles or we may stop the process at any time.

fields.label: mouDetail
fields.infoText:
- You and your representative must be available within 90 days for a face to face meeting. This may take a full day.

- If the mediator asks for more information, you need to provide this within 15 days

- If you discover new information before a meeting, you need to provide this to the mediator and the caseworker as quickly as possible 
 
- If you cannot meet any deadlines, you must tell the mediator

- The mediator will treat your information confidentially. This does not cover evidence of criminality, or facts that significantly change your tax or penalty situation.

- If you make a formal complaint about the process, the mediator will be asked to comment. This may include information you told then confidentially.

choices: I confirm that I have read and agreed to these principles. I understand this does not guarantee my application will be accepted.

sections.title: Agreement

fields.infoText: Read these principles, and get your client's agreement to them before submitting. If we accept your application, you and your client must follow these principles or we may stop the process at any time.

fields.label: mouDetail
fields.infoText:
- You and your client must be available within 90 days for a face to face meeting. This may take a full day.

- If the mediator asks for more information, you need to provide this within 15 days

- If you discover new information before a meeting, you need to provide this to the mediator and the caseworker as quickly as possible 
 
- If you or your client cannot meet any deadlines, you must tell the mediator

- The mediator will treat your client's information confidentially. This does not cover evidence of criminality, or facts that significantly change your tax or penalty situation.

- If you make a formal complaint about the process, the mediator will be asked to comment. This may include information you or your client told then confidentially.

choices: I confirm that I have explained these principles to my client and they have agreed to them. I understand this does not guarantee the application will be accepted.
